title: Fix typos in CSI Volume Plugins design doc
Propose replacing github label priority/failing-test with kind/failing-test
body:
As CI Signal Lead for 1.9 I often found myself filing issues with `priority/critical-urgent` `priority/failing-test`.  Having two priorities assigned to an issue seems... weird.  I think the idea was to encourage folks to prioritize failing tests as the most important thing.  I'm not sure how well that has worked in practice.

It would make more sense to me if we called it `kind/failing-test`, to separate from `kind/bug` or `kind/flake`.  I could then say that https://github.com/kubernetes/test-infra/issues/6095 holds true, that an issue should only ever have one priority label applied to it.

I went digging through devstats and maybe it hurts my case.  It does look like `priority/failing-test` issues get closed a little more quickly than `priority/critical-urgent` issues.  That said, I would argue it comes from effectively triaging failing tests into a bucket, not so much that the bucket has the word "priority" in it.
- [issues age|repo:kubernetes priority/failing-test](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/dashboard/db/issues-age?orgId=1&from=now-2y&to=now&var-period=w&var-repogroup_name=Kubernetes&var-repogroup=kubernetes&var-sig_name=All&var-kind_name=All&var-prio_name=failing-test&var-sig=all&var-kind=all&var-prio=failing_test)
- [issues age|repo:kubernetes priority/critical-urgent](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/dashboard/db/issues-age?orgId=1&var-period=w&var-repogroup_name=Kubernetes&var-repogroup=kubernetes&var-sig_name=All&var-kind_name=All&var-prio_name=critical-urgent&var-sig=all&var-kind=all&var-prio=critical_urgent&from=now-2y&to=now)
- [issues age|repo:kubernetes](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/dashboard/db/issues-age?orgId=1&from=now-2y&to=now&var-period=w&var-repogroup_name=Kubernetes&var-repogroup=kubernetes&var-sig_name=All&var-kind_name=All&var-prio_name=All&var-sig=all&var-kind=all&var-prio=all)
- [issues age|repo:kubernetes kind/bug priority/failing-test](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/dashboard/db/issues-age?orgId=1&from=now-2y&to=now&var-period=w&var-repogroup_name=Kubernetes&var-repogroup=kubernetes&var-sig_name=All&var-kind_name=bug&var-prio_name=failing-test&var-sig=all&var-kind=bug&var-prio=failing_test)
- [issues age|repo:kubernetes kind/bug priority/crticial-urgent](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/dashboard/db/issues-age?orgId=1&from=now-2y&to=now&var-period=w&var-repogroup_name=Kubernetes&var-repogroup=kubernetes&var-sig_name=All&var-kind_name=bug&var-prio_name=critical-urgent&var-sig=all&var-kind=bug&var-prio=critical_urgent)
- [issues age|repo:kubernetes kind/bug](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/dashboard/db/issues-age?orgId=1&from=now-2y&to=now&var-period=w&var-repogroup_name=Kubernetes&var-repogroup=kubernetes&var-sig_name=All&var-kind_name=bug&var-prio_name=All&var-sig=all&var-kind=bug&var-prio=all)

ref: trying to make github issue labels more sane kubernetes/kubernetes#57911

title: API Machinery SLIs/SLOs - Watch latency
body:
[discussion moved from [google docs](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Q5qxdeBPgTTIXZxdsFILg7kgqWhvOwY8uROEf0j5YBw/edit?ts=5a54e869#heading=h.8ftey72as5p) regarding the [API Machinery SLIs/SLOs for watch latency](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/sig-scalability/slis/apimachinery_slis.md#watch-latency)]

@zcahana:
> Would it be reasonable to extend this definition (perhaps as SLI2) to measure the e2e watch latency, i.e. from the moment a POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE is invoked, and until the corresponding watch notification is sent to each/all watchers?
>
>This would allow to reason about the latencies perceived both by individual watchers, and by the entire system.
>
>A derived SLO, if defined, can place a bound on latency, depending on the number of watchers.

@wojtek-t:
> Re this particular thing: I'm open to suggestions, but it's not easy to do in general. First: when does it start? I imagine that when the request reaches apiserver (which already makes it not really e2e). Second, how would you like to solve the problem of HA setups and clock skew.

@zcahana:
> Regarding "when does it start":
Ideally we'd start measuring when the client issues the API call, but obviously that requires some synchronization - of the clocks, a well as correlating the timestamps recorded at client/server sides.
If that turns up too complex, we can start measuring when the API server receives the request. That's indeed "less" e2e-ish, but anyway the dominant factor is expected to be the time it takes to disseminate the watch notification to the watchers.
>
> Regarding clock skews:
(handwaving) I guess we can use NTP to get a milliseconds-order synchronization in an HA setup, which is probably accurate enough for the subject matter, given the expected latencies at scale.

@wojtek-t:
> We don't require users to have any kind of NTP. And we don't want ot introduce this requirement to make some metrics reliable.

@zcahana:
> I probably misunderstood your question about clock skews. My answer was with respect to how we setup the test environment, involving multiple servers, such that their clocks are "synchronized enough" so we can derive durations (latencies) from start/end timestamps reported from different servers. That doesn't impose any requirements on users - only on the test setup.

title: cannot join network of a non running container
body:
Guys,

We are facing an issue with Kubernetes and we don't have any clue why we are facing this issue with PODS and Ingress Controller. It worked for 1-2 hours on production and post that is starts crashing and become super slow. Further, it went down automatically and our master node goes away. It was working in pre-production environment and performed well during load testing as well. But it was not good experience after making it live.  

**ingress1-production-nginx-ingress-controller-kvwbv                0/1       rpc error: code = 2 desc = failed to start container "eab6353c80d0b908935ade38f17f1847e9b48f319be7fb31a4f56438dbc81036": Error response from daemon: {"message":"cannot join network of a non running container: 0274341d2a453507e82438191c220e65c688d4a6a5eb5c7280f9d36d41159127"}   4          1h

ingress1-production-nginx-ingress-controller-lbhzp                1/1       Running 

backend-production-1736527380-zjj96                               0/1       rpc error: code = 2 desc = failed to start container "25ec7ea428ff2a17cefadfad5b5bbe575ac3b7585d711d1926e16f6123894d64": Error response from daemon: {"message":"cannot join network of a non running container: 2972634f30528325d66200a0dbf4161781fb266fbb14e84638916f04138b8d27"}   5          1h
backend-production-2877748106-090n7                               0/1       CrashLoopBackOff**  

We are using following components for our infra -

Client Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"9", GitVersion:"v1.9.0", GitCommit:"925c127ec6b946659ad0fd596fa959be43f0cc05", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2017-12-15T21:07:38Z", GoVersion:"go1.9.2", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}

2. Terraform

Server: &version.Version{SemVer:"v2.7.2", GitCommit:"8478fb4fc723885b155c924d1c8c410b7a9444e6", GitTreeState:"clean"}

Please let me know if you guys need more information because this is blocker for us to make the application live on Kuberenetes

title: Add info on KUBE_TIMEOUT in testing doc for troubleshooting
body:
Refering Doc: https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/testing.md

While following the steps detailed on the above document, the unit tests for pkg/master would consistently error with a panic (see below) and the only way to get past it is to increase the KUBE_TIMEOUT on /hack/make-rules/test.sh to something greater than 120s in the kubernetes/kubernetes repo. Thinking 300s will be a safer.  

```sh
panic: test timed out after 2m0s

goroutine 4243 [running]:
testing.startAlarm.func1()
       ~/go/src/testing/testing.go:1145 +0xf9
created by time.goFunc
       ~/go/src/time/sleep.go:170 +0x44
````
I would like to add this as a pointer to the doc, under the run all unit tests section https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/testing.md#run-all-unit-tests so it will help future readers. If there is a different place to document this or If it is better to increase the value on the script in kubernetes repo, please let me know. I can submit PR for either changes.

Below is the text I would like add. (Updated with input from @cblecker)
--- START OF TEXT
if any of unit test fail with a timeout panic (see #1594) on the testing package. you can try increasing the KUBE_TIMEOUT value as shown below.

```sh
make test KUBE_TIMEOUT=-timeout 300s
```
--- END OF TEXT

title: Sig-aws CONTRIBUTING.md should point at contributor guide
body:
The new  [contributor guide](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/tree/master/contributors/guide) is in working condition. Any SIG-specific CONTRIBUTING.md files should first point to the contributor guide, and then mention SIG-specific extra guidelines.
The goal is to have the contributor guide be the single source of truth for general contributing rules.

Make sure to:
- avoid duplication of instruction (for example, don't point people at the CLA signing document; point them to the contributor guide)
- verify all other information given is up to date and fits logically with the contributor guide.

This is in partial completion of #1413.

/sig aws

title: Out-of-tree volume plugin FAQ for storage vendors.
body:
<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
- If this is your first contribution, read our Getting Started guide https://github.com/kubernetes/community#your-first-contribution
- If you are editing SIG information, please follow these instructions: https://git.k8s.io/community/generator
  You will need to follow these steps:
  1. Edit sigs.yaml with your change 
  2. Generate docs with `make generate`. To build docs for one sig, run `make WHAT=sig-apps generate`
-->

With CSI in development, there are now two different ways to implement out-of-tree volume plugins in Kubernetes. This doc aims to demystify the differences and provide answers to common questions from storage vendors that come up while deciding between CSI and FlexVolume.

Once this is merged, I'll add a link to this doc here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/storage/volumes/#out-of-tree-volume-plugins

title: Do all tests in test/e2e_node will be ran using "make test-e2e-node"?
body:
There are two official docs about e2e test.
[End-to-End Testing in Kubernetes](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/e2e-tests.md)
[Node End-To-End tests](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/e2e-node-tests.md)
I wonder if the first one will only run the tests in folder test/e2e, and the second one will only run the tests in test/e2e_node. When I run `make test-e2e-node` ref the second doc, I see so many tests in test/e2e also run. Are there some wrong with my understanding?

title: PR document needs to mention trivial edit contribution policy
body:
I've removed this text from CONTRIBUTING.md, but we need to put it back in the PR doc when that gets scrubbed and put into the contributor guide. 

```
### Trivial Edits

Each incoming Pull Request needs to be reviewed, checked, and then merged.
While automation helps with this, each contribution also has an engineering cost. Therefore it is appreciated if you do NOT make trivial edits and fixes, but instead focus on giving the entire file a review.
If you find one grammatical or spelling error, it is likely there are more in that file, you can really make your Pull Request count by checking formatting, checking for broken links, and fixing errors and then submitting all the fixes at once to that file.
Some questions to consider:
- Can the file be improved further?
- Does the trivial edit greatly improve the quality of the content?
```

title: Mentoring Umbrella Issue
body:
We have a brand new home in the community repo for mentoring docs. We've kicked off testing for all three strategies listed on the [README](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/tree/master/mentoring). These tackle various learning styles, audiences, and our needs of continuous contributor growth. 

This is a task list of where we need help, engagement, and/or your opinions. I'll add the corresponding issues/docs to each once they are set; they will have more detail and context. 

- [ ] [Outreachy](outreachy.org)
* Need more sponsoring organizations, SIGs, and mentors. $6500/per intern. 
* Google and CNCF picked up the sponsorship this semester for the two CLI folks we have. CNCF will sponsor one intern per semester.

- [ ] Group Mentoring: 
* Need SIGs/WGs interest in mentoring for a certain ladder level (made up example: SIG Networking needs more approvers)
* Need areas of growth / skills for each ladder level. See the [mentee guide](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/mentoring/group-mentee-guide.md) for development areas and comment there. This will shape our workshops and future of Kubernetes learning and development. 
  * What does a new member need to know to be successful? 
  * What skills do reviewers need? Approvers? 
See also: #1514 - scroll for comment about "code reviews the k8s way"

- [ ] #1753 & Doc -[Meet Our Contributors](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/mentoring/meet-our-contributors.md)
* Need volunteers to [sign up](https://goo.gl/uhEJ33). Our next session is Feb 7th at 730am PST (no volunteers needed) and 1pm PST (needed). 
* 30 min AMA style like user office hours and the last half dedicated to a live peer code review. 

- [ ] [Google Summer of Code](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/mentoring/google-summer-of-code.md)
* Need mentors, projects, et al.



/sig contributor-experience
/assign

title: Formalize the concept of subprojects
body:
This is based on / inspired by a [SIG Architecture proposal to expand SIG metadata and flesh out OWNERS](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1FHauGII5LNVM-dZcNfzYZ-6WRs9RoPctQ4bw5dczrkk/edit#)

This is driven by a steering committee goal of ensuring that our organizational structure maps to our code structure.

> Every part of the Kubernetes code and documentation should be owned by a Special Interest Group (SIG). However, many SIGs have multiple significant subprojects with distinct (though sometimes overlapping) sets of contributors and owners, who act as subproject’s technical leaders: responsible for vision and direction and overall design, choose/approve change proposal (KEP) approvers, field technical escalations, etc. We should formally recognize that.

> For example, SIG Network potentially could be divided into multiple subprojects: pod networking (CNI, etc.), Service, Ingress, DNS, and Network policy. SIG Apps has the workload APIs, Helm, and Kompose. SIG Cluster Lifecycle has kubeadm, kops, kubespray, minikube, etc. SIG API machinery has apiserver, client libraries, API discovery and OpenAPI, CRD, API aggregation, and admission extension. In addition to Kubelet proper, SIG Node has multiple CRI implementations underway. Maybe some of these subprojects should be grouped, but hopefully you get the idea.

I'd like to start by implementing this concept in [`sigs.yaml`](/sigs.yaml). This ensures the information is machine-readable, generated README's contain human-readable information, and we start with a single source of truth.

Strawman:
- a sig may have N subprojects
- a subproject must have a name
- a subproject must have 1 - N OWNERS files associated with it
- the OWNERS files define the root of the repos/subdirectories owned by the subproject
- a subproject may have a description
- a subproject may have one or more meetings
- meetings can have different uris for video, agenda, recordings, etc.

Looking at SIG Apps as an example:
- A "Workloads API" subproject could potentially span multiple subdirs and repos
- A "Charts" subproject spans the kubernetes/charts repo
- A "Helm" subproject could potentially span kubernetes/helm and kubernetes-helm/* repos

Looking at SIG Contributor Experience as an example:
- A "Mentorship" subproject would own the docs in kubernetes/community that related to mentorship
- A "Community Management" subproject would own the docs in multiple subdirs of kubernetes/community

I am putting together an implementation based on this strawman with a _total guess_ of single-repo subprojects based on first-pass by @bgrant0607, so we have a concrete example to iterate on.  The intent isn't to voluntold SIG's into owning repos, but to identify where our gaps lie.

/sig contributor-experience
/sig apps
Since I mention you two as examples

/committee steering
/priority important-soon
/assign

title: Initial implementation of subprojects
body:
Initial implementation of #1673

A subproject is a one-to-many mapping of a name to a list of
OWNERS urls.  This allows for a subproject to be a single repo (eg:
helm), or a subproject to be a list of multiple subdirectories across
one or more repos (eg: workloads api)

Strawman assignment of single repo subprojects per an initial mapping
from @bgrant0607

title: SIG lead lifecycle needs to be documented
body:
When a SIG lead moves on we need to document a few things. There are [pending governance things](https://github.com/kubernetes/steering/blob/master/backlog.md) here but this issue will document the technical changes at a minimum.

- Old lead 
  - unsubscribe from their sig leaders list.
  - Removal as leader from sigs.yaml
- New lead
  - Subscribe to the sig leaders list. 
  - Need the Zoom credentials to record meetings
  - Need Youtube collaboration URL, perhaps a new one should be generated? 
  - Addition as leader in sigs.yaml and then [regenerate the pages](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/tree/master/generator). 

Announcements to:

- That SIG's internal list
- kubernetes-dev list
- Mention in the announcements of a community meeting

title: Bot should respond with the final step when a PR is accepted
body:
A new contributor gave me some bot feedback. All the intermediate steps were fine (bot had links to docs, etc.) but one thing he wasn't clear on was what the next step when his PR got accepted. 

Perhaps something like "Your PR has been accepted, you're done! No action is required on your part. Check the _merge queue_ if you're interested in more details" 

/sig contributor-experience

title: ContribEx Guide Needs to Recommend Mailing List Best Practices
body:
<!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY! 

If you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).
-->

**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:

/kind feature


**What happened**:
As a Kubernetes community member, it is difficult to attain a good signal-to-noise ratio with regards to GitHub notifications and mailing list messages. 

**What you expected to happen**:
I'd like to get some guidance on how to be an effective communicator in the Kubernetes community. In other words, not be deluged by all the e-mail. Specifically, what to do with GitHub and Gmail to surface the pertinent content and purge the less personally meaningful content.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:
Join as a Member, help out with more than one SIG.

**Anything else we need to know?**:
N/A

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): N/A
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: N/A
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): N/A
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): N/A
- Install tools: N/A
- Others:

cc @castrojo @bgrant0607 @idvoretskyi 
/sig contributor-experience
/area contributor-guide

title: Doc building script needs to be automatic
body:
We are currently getting the contrib guide, mentorship guide, and KEPs imported into the doc site.

To do this we must checkout the website repo locally, run `./update-imported-docs community.yml`, then submit a PR to the docs team to update these docs. 

It would be nice if this script did:

- Make it so we don't have to specify each and every page in `community.yaml`, we should just be able to say "build everything in contributor/guide". So, specifying a directory should be enough.

title: Proposal: Add service port ranges support
body:
<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
- If this is your first contribution, read our Getting Started guide https://github.com/kubernetes/community#your-first-contribution
- If you are editing SIG information, please follow these instructions: https://git.k8s.io/community/generator
  You will need to follow these steps:
  1. Edit sigs.yaml with your change 
  2. Generate docs with `make generate`. To build docs for one sig, run `make WHAT=sig-apps generate`
-->

There are several applications like SIP apps or RTP which needs a lot of ports to run multiple calls or media streams. Currently there is no way to allow a range in ports in spec. So essentially users may have to do this:

```
- name: sip-udp5060
  containerPort: 5060
  protocol: UDP
- name: sip-udp5061
  containerPort: 5061
  protocol: UDP
  ...
- name: sip-udp5559
  containerPort: 5559
  protocol: UDP
```

Doing above for 500 ports is not pretty. Can we have a way to allow port ranges like 5060-5559?

## Objective

This proposal builds off of earlier requests to [Support port ranges in services](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/23864) and aims to document all the requirements of supporting port ranges in services.


/sig network

title: Add new repository structure doc.
Meet Our Contributors needs Volunteers
body:
From Mentoring Umbrella Issue #1672 

[Doc explaining MOC](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/mentoring/meet-our-contributors.md)

We need more volunteers for the Ask Us Anything portion and code peer reviewers live. Volunteers can mark their availability [on this sheet (tab for MOC)](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OKc4h-0QLKCbncSloRf_gYklpHYVyNxZmfEM9hlK1xQ/edit?usp=sharing). Right now we are only running once a month (first Wednesday) at 730am PST/3:30pm UTC and ideally would like to run twice a month or covering two timezone editions (western and APAC) in the same day. 

Expectations of volunteers -

- Be on 5 mins early
- Be prepared to give advice on contribution process, membership, navigating the kubernetes seas, testing, and general questions about you and your path to open source/kubernetes.
- We will be using video chat (zoom but live streaming through YouTube) but voice only is fine if you are more comfortable with that
- Be willing to provide suggestions and feedback to make this better!

TODO:
Add expectations for volunteers to meet-our-contributors.md

/sig contributor-experience
/assign

title: Change KEP state from accepted to draft
body:
This PR is a proposal to make the initial state of a KEP more clear.
There have been misunderstandings on the means because of the way
accepted has been used elsewhere on the project.

For example, some reviewing the Application object/CRD PR though expected meant implementable or that this was the accepted design direction that would be expected to implement. Since this is a new process I would argue the naming should follow the [principle of least astonishment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment) and attempt to be intuitive even to those not familiar with the process (which is most people at the moment).

This proposed change moves the term to draft which is used buy other projects
such as the IETF standards track.

/cc @jdumars @bgrant0607 @jbeda 

/sig architecture

title: Confusion over states in the KEP-1 proposal
body:
This issue arises out of a discussion in SIG-Apps today, and applies to 0001-kubernetes-enhancement-proposal-process.md

For background, there has been movement in the community to use the KEP process for more general standards (e.g. CRDs, conventions, or ecosystem tooling), not just changes to Kubernetes core. This is causing confusion.

The states defined in the KEP-1 (implementable, implemented, deferred, etc.) are significantly different than the states define for RFCs, Rust RFCs, PEPs, and similar specification processes. This is causing confusion about how to actually use KEPs.

Specifically, it appears to be a process designed to handle only _one implementation_ of any given proposal. (`implementable`/`implemented`/`deferred`). Thus it seems only useful for one project that admits only one canonical implementation of a KEP. So it becomes generally unusable when trying to define interchange formats, protocols, schemata, etc.

The core confusion comes from conflating _specification_ and _implementation_. First, an implementation can be achieved against a non-existent or poor specification. Whether something is _implementable_ or _implemented_ does not speak to the quality of the specification. Neither should the existence of an implementation foreclose the possibility of writing a good specification. Second, a specification does not necessarily need "an implementation" to be useful. One might "specify" the purpose or meaning of labels or annotations, but without having "an implementation". (KEP-1, for example, does not have "an implementation".)

As a remedial action, I would propose that we do one of two things:

- Agree to not use KEP-1 for anything but proposals to extend the functionality of Kubernetes core, and leave everyone else (SIGs, etc) to figure out their own process
- Supersede KEP-1 with a new KEP that outlines states as they are explained in [the RFC process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Request_for_Comments) or another standards process that is not strongly tied to just one canonical implementation.

Proposal: HPA using external metrics
body:
This proposal describes an extension to the HPA v2 API that would allow autoscaling based on metrics coming from outside kubernetes cluster. This is not possible using existing API.

Common use-cases are autoscaling pods using a hosted service (ex. hosted message queue) or autoscaling in systems that have (so far) only partly moved to Kubernetes.

https://github.com/kubernetes/community/pull/1802 describes External Metrics API used internally by HPA to retrieve metrics. 

/sig-autoscaling

title: Proposal: External Metrics API
body:
This proposal introduces External Metrics API. It is based on existing Custom Metrics API and it provides metrics not related to any Kubernetes object.

https://github.com/kubernetes/community/pull/1801 describes how HPA would use this API.

/sig-instrumentation

title: Mentoring Proposal: Long Term Buddy/Guide Program
body:
Inspiration: Buddy/Guide program @ gophercon. New folks to Go and/or the conference (Buddies) are paired up with more experienced folks (Guides) to have a meal and discuss how to get the Buddy better engaged in the community plus the event. (tl;dr not all details)

K8s implementation:
We can obviously use this at KubeCon as well but longer term strategy would be similar to 1:1 matching mentor programs that we are used to with a twist. Instead of goal setting, regular meetings, etc. in the traditional approach, this would be a one time, one hour session with a contributor at a higher membership level than the individual looking for guidance. 

Tools required:
Matching [form](https://goo.gl/forms/iBmem15vnNKwmSPH2) - we can adjust questions and logic on this one to improve and target this activity. This will be included in the mentoring documentation on GH and K8s.io.

Mentor expectations here would be one hour. The mentor isn't expected to know all of the answers to the questions but should be able to point them to better resources. This will require knowledge of how the community communicates, finding documentation, etc. 

cc/@chris-short who has offered to help and/or lead TBU

Thoughts?

/sig contributor-experience

title: Updating OWNERS files
body:
It's been an year since the first population of the OWNERS files in https://github.com/kubernetes/contrib/issues/1389. 

* Some folks have moved on and no longer reviewing or approving changes that they are responsible for
* New folks have adding code who may make good reviewers if not approvers
* Can we get some data on which reviewers / approvers are not really doing what they are supposed to do? (so we can request if we can drop them from the file(s))?
* There is a concept of a SIG in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/OWNERS_ALIASES, but very few OWNERS files use these groups from OWNERS_ALIASES. Do we want to move to a model where we favor the sig groupings over individuals? Is that upto sig(s)? Do we want to tell them that they should review code under their purview and make the change?

It's probably time to update reviewers and approvers again...

title: Documenting the revert process (Avoid the github revert button)
body:
- Use `git revert SHA` where SHA is the hash of the commit you wish to revert
- Push this commit to a new branch in your own repo
- Use the commit/branch to file a PR

Essentially avoid pushing the button in github web UI. This creates unnecessary branches in the kubernetes main repository that someone has to go clean up. The bots notice such merges and notifies kubernetes-dev channel as well. following process above will avoid that notifications too

title: Require all k/* repositories to have CONTRIBUTING.md
body:
All K8s subrepositories should have a CONTRIBUTING.md file, which at the minimum should point to 
https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/guide/README.md. Care should be taken that all information is in sync with the contributor guide.

Subrepositories may also have contributing guidelines specific to that repository. They should be explicitly documented and explained in the CONTRIBUTING.md.

The first step to working on this issue is to create a task list of k/subrepositories that need to have issues/PRs filed against to rectify this.

/sig contributor-experience
/area contributor-guide
/help

title: Contributor guide README should clarify special subrepository contributing guidelines
body:
See also #1832 .

Certain subrepositories of the Kubernetes Project may have (and will have) additional or special contributing guidelines. Currently, the contributor guide only mentions that SIGs may have additional guidelines, but is silent about subrepositories.

Add clarifying language that contributors should double check if the particular repository they're contributing to has additional requirements or differnet processes.

/sig contributor-experience
/area contributor-guide

title: Formal scalability processes design proposal
body:
We've been having various scattered discussions on how scalability/performance regressions are affecting k8s and its eng productivity. To try to solve those issues, I've assimilated some of my thoughts for formal scalability processes into [this google doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Jv_QbehMTf0t2YVS4pYM_iSqWpg777JDRRbIUKXErYI/edit?usp=sharing), which changed into the current form after some great inputs from sig-scale folks (@wojtek-t, @wasylkowski-a, @gmarek, @porridge - thanks!).

This PR is a markdown version of that doc. PTAL

/cc @thockin @smarterclayton (as steering committee members)
/cc @spiffxp (as sig-testing lead)
/cc @wojtek-t (as sig-scalability lead)

title: Simplify membership ladder
body:
Merge *maintainer* responsibilities into *project owner*

Why are we doing this:

- The scope of the Kubernetes project is such that having a role for holistic maintenance of the entire project in all capacities is not practical.  Scoping responsibilities to specific *subprojects* within the Kubernetes project is feasible.
- Through automation improvements direct write access to the kubernetes/kubernetes will no longer be necessary for maintenance of the project going forward.

PR details:

- **Remove *maintainer* role and merge responsibilities into *owner* role**
- Rename *owner* to *subproject owner* and frame responsibilities in the context of a subproject
- Rename references to area / component to subproject
- Remove references to kubernetes-reviewers GitHub team
- Remove references to kubernetes incubator

title: Integrate CNI traffic shaping plugin with Kubernetes
body:
<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
- If this is your first contribution, read our Getting Started guide https://github.com/kubernetes/community#your-first-contribution
- If you are editing SIG information, please follow these instructions: https://git.k8s.io/community/generator
  You will need to follow these steps:
  1. Edit sigs.yaml with your change 
  2. Generate docs with `make generate`. To build docs for one sig, run `make WHAT=sig-apps generate`
-->

Currently the kubenet code supports applying basic traffic shaping during pod setup. This will happen if bandwidth-related annotations have been added to the pod's metadata, for example:

    {
        "kind": "Pod",
        "metadata": {
            "name": "iperf-slow",
            "annotations": {
                "kubernetes.io/ingress-bandwidth": "10M",
                "kubernetes.io/egress-bandwidth": "10M"
            }
        }
    }

Our current implementation uses the linux tc to add an download(ingress) and upload(egress) rate limiter using 1 root qdisc, 2 class(one for ingress and one for egress) and 2 filter(one for ingress and one for egress attached to the ingress and egress classes respectively).

Kubelet CNI code doesn't support it yet. However, there is enough functionality for us to add a simple CNI plugin to replicate the behavior we have today in kubenet if we feel this is an important feature. In fact, CNI has already supported traffic shaping plugin.

/sig network

title: Other unanswered questions in cherry-picks.md
body:
I made a PR against the master branch of kubernetes, and it needs to be cherry-picked to some older releases.  I have read https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/cherry-picks.md but it leaves me with some questions.

cherry-picks.md says, in the section on "Propose a Cherry Pick", that "Cherrypicks are managed with labels and milestones", and the last part is a hyperlink to https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/guide/release-notes.md --- which is probably not what is intended.

I am very much in the dark regarding labels and milestones.  cherry-picks.md says "first ensure the following labels are on the original master branch PR" but I do not know how to make that happen.  I do not even know whether it is something I do for myself (if so, how?) or something that I get somebody else to do (if so, who?).

When there are multiple releases that need a cherry-pick, cherry-picks.md does not say whether they are done serially  or in parallel.  As noted in #994, cherry-picks.md does not say how to handle multiple cherry-picks.

title: Add CodeTriage badge to kubernetes/kubernetes
body:
Adds a badge showing the number of people helping this repo on CodeTriage.

[![Open Source Helpers](https://www.codetriage.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/badges/users.svg)](https://www.codetriage.com/kubernetes/kubernetes)

CodeTriage is an Open Source app that is designed to make contributing to Open Source projects easier. It works by sending subscribers a few open issues in their inbox. If subscribers get busy, there is an algorithm that backs off issue load so they do not get overwhelmed

[Read more about the CodeTriage project](https://www.codetriage.com/what).

Your project was picked by the human, @schneems. They selected it from the projects submitted to https://www.codetriage.com and hand edited the PR. How did your project get added to [CodeTriage](https://www.codetriage.com/what)? Roughly over 1 year ago, [muriithi](https://github.com/muriithi) added this project to CodeTriage in order to start contributing. Since then, 416 people have subscribed to help this repo.

Adding a badge invites people to help contribute to your project. It also lets developers know that others are invested in the longterm success and maintainability of the project.

You can see an example of a CodeTriage badge on these popular OSS READMEs:

- [![Email clients like GMAIL do not render SVG images](https://www.codetriage.com/rails/rails/badges/users.svg)](https://www.codetriage.com/rails/rails) https://github.com/rails/rails
- [![Email clients like GMAIL do not render SVG images](https://www.codetriage.com/crystal-lang/crystal/badges/users.svg)](https://www.codetriage.com/crystal-lang/crystal) https://github.com/crystal-lang/crystal

While I am a bot, this PR was manually reviewed and monitored by a human - @schneems. My job is writing commit messages and handling PR logistics.

If you have any questions, you can reply back to this PR and they will be answered by @schneems. If you do not want a badge right now, no worries, close the PR, you will not hear from me again.

Thanks for making your project Open Source! Any feedback is greatly appreciated.

title: Umbrella issue for reviews
body:
This tracks issues/content for the "How to do reviews the Kubernetes Way" section of the contributor's guide:

Known Docs:
- [Tim’s (thockin) Live Code Review](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WVobATuodV0T3F22CXhsdYpOk5K7D-uKO9j-0QUuLdU/edit#heading=h.2oi459gj6360)
- Clayton's Review Notes will go here. 
- [BPs for better, faster reviews](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/pull-requests.md#best-practices-for-faster-reviews)
- [Collaboration](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/collab.md)
- [GoLang Code Reviews](https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/CodeReview)
- [GoLang Code Review Comments](https://github.com/spiffxp/community/blob/09604a27aa2c50defe42592305b742649d74b577/contributors/devel/owners.md)
- [Code Reviews using OWNERS files](https://github.com/spiffxp/community/blob/09604a27aa2c50defe42592305b742649d74b577/contributors/devel/owners.md)
- [K8s Coding Conventions (file location may change)](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/coding-conventions.md)
- [Cherry Pick Reviews](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/cherry-picks.md)
- PR workflow [.dia](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/pr_workflow.dia) and [.png](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/pr_workflow.png)
- [K8s Bot Commands](https://github.com/kubernetes/test-infra/blob/master/commands.md)
Watching for release-note needed changes, how to feed into the docs process

### Docs/Guides/Content Needed
Common problems?
Discourse in / on PRs, issues, etc. - good, bad, ugly?

### Kops
- Vendoring is different between subprojects. kubernetes/kubernetes uses godep, we use submodules, and maybe dep soon
- docs are generated differently in kubernetes/kubernetes and this causes some confusion with new contributors with code generated docs.
- CI is different with Travis runs, and e2e is sorta the same, but tests kops differently
- our integration testing framework with terraform is unique, because how we are testing that install works, instead of testing that k8s works
- API modifications and additions are far less formal in kops than other projects but are still reviewed with a lot of deliberate focus.

### Charts

[Helm Charts](https://github.com/kubernetes/charts/blob/master/REVIEW_GUIDELINES.md)

### Docs

[Tech Reviewers for Docs](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1RxXC2V74c4b6DBJwsgAn-y33WlDLk1_XRLc-fxWm9y0/edit?usp=sharing_eil&ts=5a9d06d1)

### External Resources (that can be used?)

[Practical Lessons in Code Reviews](https://medium.com/@salsita/practical-lessons-in-peer-code-review-b4dbc84e88d3)
[@math_rachel tweet](https://twitter.com/math_rachel/status/939968380202762240) - reach out to paris for credit copy

title: Support client certificate revocation
body:
Need help regarding revoking a already issued client certificates.

Steps to reproduce:

1. I added the groups information in the idtoken of oidcUser1 and configured the same groups 
using "--oidc-groups-claim" in kubernetes

2. I've created created client certificate and key for use with kubectl.
```
openssl req -newkey rsa:2048  -out oidcuser.csr -nodes -keyout oidcuser.key -subj /CN=oidcUser/O=group1/O=group2
```
which works fine with
kubectl config set-credentials oidcuser --client-certificate=oidcuser.pem --client-key=oidcuser.key

4. Problem is if the user groups for oidcuser changes, then the certificate still have stale group information.

5. Is there any way we can configure apiserver to reject such certificates with assuming we have info related to certificate, key in hand?

title: No default iptable rule to allow incoming traffic to port 6443 on master (Kubernetes 1.9.3)
body:
<!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY! 

If you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).
-->

** BUG REPORT**:

> Uncomment only one, leave it on its own line: 
>
 /kind bug
@sig/cluster-lifecycle/kubeadm
> /kind feature


**What happened**:

While deploying kubernetes v1.9.3 cluster using `kubeadm` on Centos 7.4, nodes couldn't reach master API on port 6443.

The command  `# kubeadm join --token 32fcfd.d1eec8c99efe1cfb 10.0.32.140:6443 --discovery-token-ca-cert-hash sha256:6931045ca75e9a9deb08b616467367d5e5d91185adb9bae3455c7b3d68f97800`  on nodes showing the following error

Error:
Trying to connect to API Server "10.0.32.140:6443"
[discovery] Created cluster-info discovery client, requesting info from "https://10.0.32.140:6443"
[discovery] Failed to request cluster info, will try again: [Get https://10.0.32.140:6443/api/v1/namespaces/kube-public/configmaps/cluster-info:

**What you expected to happen**:
Nodes should be able to communicate with master API, fetch the cluster-info and join the cluster.
**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

Follow the procedure https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/independent/install-kubeadm/ 

**Anything else we need to know?**:

After the investigation, it is observers that, the default firewall configuration on `master` node, not permitting incoming traffic to port 6443 in table `IN_public_allow`. After manually adding the incoming rule
 to the table,  nodes are able to communicate with master API and join the cluster.

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: 
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): CentOS 7.4
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): 3.10.0-693.17.1.el7.x86_64
- Install tools: kubeadm
- Others:

title: WIP: Design of local storage dynamic provisioning
KEP: kubeadm config HA support
body:
This KEP elaborates on the approach suggested by @fabriziopandini in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubeadm/issues/706#issuecomment-368068828 to augment the existing `kubeadm-config` with additional master-specific ConfigMaps in order to enable HA upgrades in the future.

An alternative approach (elaborated on in the KEP) would be to augment the existing `kubeadm-config` directly without the use of additional ConfigMaps. The multiple ConfigMap approach makes more sense to me so that's what I decided to propose. If there is a lot of opposition to this approach, then I'm happy to draft a new KEP.

I will also work on prototyping this as we agreed. I just wanted to get something out there to get a more serious discussion moving.

cc @timothysc @luxas @fabriziopandini @stealthybox @mbert

title: Deprecate kubernetes-incubator in favor of kubernetes-sigs
body:
/committee steering
/sig contributor-experience
/assign
ref: kubernetes/test-infra#7184

We have https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/kubernetes-repositories.md sorta spelling out kubernetes-sigs, and we have https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/incubator.md spelling out kubernetes-incubator.

There's been lots of mailing list and meeting talk about deprecating incubator and instead using kubernetes-sigs as the way forward.  But we're sorta lacking in official looking docs

I'd like to:
- ~add a note to incubator calling it deprecated~
- add a note to our list of orgs calling out kuberentes-sigs in use
- spell out the process to get a new repo created in kubernetes-sigs
  - consensus from sig leads
  - (process debt cleanup) spell out subprojects owned by sig
  - e-mail steering committee asking for repo to be created
  - start repo based on kubernetes-template-project

title: [bug] Stateful Set: Dynamic Provisioning of PV/PVC
body:
## Objective
Create pods with persistent volumes to store large amounts of data that is regularly synced.  The data should persist even if the other modules of the pod are changed or updated.  If a persistent volume is made inactive (for example, scaling down or when restarting the stateful set), when it is re-mounted again by another/new pod, data syncing should resume from when the persistent was previously made inactive; i.e. data should be retained.

## Current behavior
After the persistent volume is disconnected, when resuming, data is reset and syncing starts as if the the persistent volume is empty.

## How to reproduce:
1. Create the stateful set as below
2. Check the logs of the `event-watcher` container of the "parity set"

```
$ kubectl logs parity-set-1 -c event-watcher --namespace parity-rp

# Example log:
getBlockNumber:
 => 103482
```

This number displayed under getBlockNumber is the currently synced block.
If the persistent volume works as intended, this number should resume from approximately where it was when the pod is disconnected.  If it starts again at `0` upon restarting of the pod/PV connection, it means that the data from the previous sync has not persisted.

3. Restart pods: either by scaling to 1 and scaling back up to 2 (checking `parity-set-1`) or by deleting the stateful set and re-creating (can check both pods)

```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: parity-rp
  labels:
    name: parity-rp
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: parity-config
  namespace: parity-rp
data:
  config.toml: |-
    [parity]
    mode = "active"
    mode_timeout = 300
    mode_alarm = 3600
    auto_update = "critical"
    release_track = "stable"
    public_node = false
    no_download = false
    no_consensus = false
    base_path = "/parity-data"
    db_path = "/parity-data/chains"
    keys_path = "/parity-data/keys"
    chain = "ropsten"

    [ui]
    disable = true

    [rpc]
    disable = false
    port = 8545
    interface = "0.0.0.0"
    cors = "null"
    apis = ["web3", "eth", "net"]
    hosts = ["all"]
---
kind: StorageClass
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: parity-ssd
  namespace: parity-rp
provisioner: kubernetes.io/gce-pd
parameters:
  type: pd-ssd
  zones: us-west1-a
reclaimPolicy: Retain
---
apiVersion: apps/v1beta1
kind: StatefulSet
metadata:
  name: parity-set
  namespace: parity-rp
  labels:
    app: parity-set
spec:
  replicas: 2
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: parity-set
  serviceName: parity-set
  template:
    metadata:
      name: parity-set
      labels:
        app: parity-set
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: parity
          image: "parity/parity:stable-release"
          imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
          command: ["/parity/parity"]
          args: ["--config", "/config/config.toml"]
          ports:
            - containerPort: 8545
              protocol: TCP
              name: rcp-port
          livenessProbe:
            tcpSocket:
              port: 8545
            initialDelaySeconds: 60
          volumeMounts:
            - name: parity-config
              mountPath: /config
              readOnly: true
            - name: parity-data
              mountPath: /parity-data
        - name: event-watcher
          # TEMPORARY TEST IMAGE
          image: "yzhang1994/eth-node-checker"
          imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
          command: ["npm"]
          args: ["start"]
          env:
            - name: "WEB3_URL"
              value: "http://localhost:8545"
      volumes:
      - name: parity-config
        configMap:
          name: parity-config
  volumeClaimTemplates:
  - metadata:
      name: parity-data
      namespace: parity-rp
    spec:
      accessModes: ["ReadWriteOnce"]
      storageClassName: "parity-ssd"
      resources:
        requests:
          storage: 200Gi
```

title: [RFC] PodRestriction proposal
body:
This is a proposal for a new policy object (and associated admission controller) that adds basic restrictions to most fields on a Pod. This is motivated by a desire to unify the various policies we have now (which all behave in slightly different ways), and to unblock expanding the set of restricted fields. Furthermore, it aims to solve some of the key usability problems with PodSecurityPolicies, such as the inability to compose policies and the difficulty in binding policies.

**Help Wanted:** I don't actually have time to own the implementation of this proposal, so I'm looking for community members who are interested in realizing this. If we decide to move forward with this approach, my hope is that we can consolidate some of the efforts around other new restriction policies.

**Question**: Should this be rolled up into the overall [policy proposal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ht8wpj4j9YfAA7aVv9Yn3Ci1T_MLMWt0DBr0QmxI2OM/edit#heading=h.6l8mozsiyzb1) or something like [OPA](http://www.openpolicyagent.org/docs/kubernetes-admission-control.html)? Alternatively, should this use a path-based OPA-style API?

Fix for https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/60001

/sig auth

title: setting up e2e environment is not compatible with LibreSSL
body:
I was trying to run `go run hack/e2e.go -- --up` and I got this error:

```
+ ./easyrsa init-pki
140735555179400:error:0E065068:configuration file routines:STR_COPY:variable has no value:/BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/libressl/libressl-22/libressl/crypto/conf/conf_def.c:573:line 3

Easy-RSA error:

Missing or invalid OpenSSL
Expected to find openssl command at: openssl
++ date +%s
+ ./easyrsa --batch --req-cn=35.225.178.231@1521642494 build-ca nopass
140735555179400:error:0E065068:configuration file routines:STR_COPY:variable has no value:/BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/libressl/libressl-22/libressl/crypto/conf/conf_def.c:573:line 3
```
I am using MacOS High Sierra (10.13.3). The default `openssl` binary points to LibreSSL, which is not compatible with easyrsa. I had to `export PATH=/usr/local/Cellar/openssl/1.0.2n/bin:$PATH` before continuing.

title: Create "good first issue" label
body:
The way it is now:

We have the "help-wanted" label, which according to [its description](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/15b507ad2f38b5943bc03d0362416c6483665c28/contributors/devel/help-wanted.md) should cover issues which are suitable for work by novice contributors. However, that's not how that label is being used; instead, it's being used for issues which are not making progess because they need additional expertise, input, or large time commitments.  Mostly, these issues require quite advanced knowledge of Kubernetes.  Examples:  [60023](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/60023), [56567](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/56567).

This means that would-be new contributors, looking for their first place to hack on Kubernetes, can't figure out where to start.  We could try to change member's behavior in using the "help wanted" tag, but that seems unlikely to be successful.

What we should do:

1. Add the "good first issue" label to automation and all repos that want it.  This includes creating the /good-first-issue and /remove-good-first-issue commands for Prow, and writing a description.
2. Amend the description to the "help wanted" label to reflect its actual use.
3. Share the new label, and an explanation of how "help wanted" and "good first issue" are distinct, with kubernetes-dev, the community meeting and the SIG leads.

The choice of "good first issue" here is because Github has public filters for that label.  While other text, such as "for-new-contributors" or "help wanted/easy" might be preferable, I believe that the use of Github's existing label will make things easier for folks who know Github but not Kubernetes.

body:

-->
Updates kubernetes/kubernetes#39845
Feature issue kubernetes/features#135

This PR updates the seccomp design doc to indicate that we are enabling a default seccomp profile: docker/default. It pulls a few pieces from #660, but does not include the seccomp spec. The reasoning here is that we can simply enable docker/default as the first step and see how it works. If strong needs of a different default k8s seccomp profile come up, we can add that later.

title: Improve docs for generators
body:
Documentation for generators could be improved by explaining more details about how it works.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Read https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/api_changes.md#generate-clientset
- Read https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/generating-clientset.md
- Try to move internal types from one API group to another

**Expected result:**
PROFIT!

**Actual result:**
Generated [clientsets use old types and don't compile](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/61608#issuecomment-375765633):

> W0323 18:55:08.870] pkg/client/clientset_generated/internalclientset/typed/extensions/internalversion/podsecuritypolicy.go:38:42: undefined: extensions.PodSecurityPolicy

In this case, it's unclear what the logic it uses and why it doesn't use types from a new API group.

@kubernetes/sig-api-machinery-misc

title: possible relnotes improvements
body:
While reviewing the draft 1.10 release notes I had the following thoughts for future enhancements:

* add a table of contents:  this does appear to happen as they render elsewhere later in the publication flow, but would make some aspects of review easier on this very long document
* add a security section (could relate to issue #1568 to have a special notation so these are easily queried for the notes)
* add sections for new alpha, graduated alpha to beta, and graduated beta to ga items
* build a linter to check basic misspeillings, backticking of dash dash command line parameters, probably many many other things the rel note wrangler regularly manually does

/sig docs

title: Copying Brian Grant's article on declarative application management from Drive
body:
There was an ask in the [Google Doc](https://docs.google.com/a/arpaia.co/document/d/1cLPGweVEYrVqQvBLJg6sxV-TrE5Rm2MNOBA_cxZP2WU/edit?disco=AAAABWmp15I) to add this document to this repo, so I ran a gdoc to markdown conversion script and went through and fixed up a few formatting errors. I didn't make any changes to content, although I did make some edits to formatting so that GitHub markdown rendering worked well.

I noticed that the [WG Apply README](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/tree/master/wg-apply) links to the Google Drive folder which contains the original, so I'm not sure if we want to just leave that as the canonical place for resources. Happy to close this out if that's the case.

title: Umbrella issue for Community Maintenance tasks
body:
This is a list of things we should audit, see https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/sig-contributor-experience/community-maintenance.md for more details.

Feel free to assign yourself to a section


### Slack
Assignee: @parispittman

- [ ] Channels - Anything out of place or not following the guidelines? 
  - [ ] Close unused channels. 
  - [ ] Check to see if there is a purpose, pinned documents like agendas, and other best practices being used in the channel. These are not required but are useful.
- [ ] Audit the Integrations and apps
- [ ] Audit the user tokens
- [x] Audit the Emojis
- [ ] Generate a Slack data report to share with the community (optional)

### GitHub

- [x] Audit Org admin permissions
- [ ] Audit Integrations
- [ ] Check Label usage (education, deprecation, etc)
- [ ] Is the PR and/or issue message still good/the best?
- [ ] Check kubernetes/community/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE
- [ ] Where’s the issue template located? 

### Calendars
Assignee: @castrojo

- [x] Check that the calendar works
  - Go to http://k8s.io/community and follow the flow
- [ ] Make sure all SIG, WG, and other community meetings are showing - especially check new groups that were created in the last quarter
- [ ] Make sure that invites have more than one owner, shared with the mailing list distro, and have an agenda attached plus zoom URL and telephone dial information.

### SIGS

- [ ] Ensure everyone in `sigs.yaml` is subscribed to sigs-leads mailing list
- [ ] Ensure that chairs and leads are accurate in the `sigs.yaml`

### YouTube
Assignee: @castrojo

- [ ] Check sharing on all the playlists
  - Should only be shared with leads or people appointed by leads
  - Either remove other people or regenerate a new collaboration URL
- [x] Check admin permissions on the Kubernetes account
- [x] Fix any videos accidentally tagged as unlisted 
- [x] Generate a YouTube traffic report to share with the community (optional)

### Zoom

- [ ] Ensure leads have access to their upgraded Zoom account
- [ ] If appropriate change the password if a SIG has changed leadership 
  - Contact CNCF to adjust upgraded licenses if necessary
- [ ] Audit kubernetes.io GSuite - this is primarily needed to create associated resources like GoogleGroups and the Google Cloud organization.  Accounts in  this domain cost the CNCF actual money, so are not available for individuals. Three steering committee members will hold the keys to three accounts on the domain, which can be used to create `@kubernetes.io` groups as needed.
  - Volunteers (Ask for new representatives from the steering committee if election turnover affects this list):
    - Joe Beda (@jbeda)
    - Brendan Burns (@brendandburns)
    - Tim Hockin (@thockin)

### Community Meeting

- [ ] Generate an archive of the [communtiy meeting notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VQDIAB0OqiSjIHI8AWMvSdceWhnz56jNpZrLs6o7NJY/edit#heading=h.2gp5yf2snwg5) for the quarter if necessary
  - [ ] Ensure the retrospective section has links to the retrospective for the releases
  - [x] Ensure the demo section is filled out and demos are assigned dates
  - [x] Ensure the [agenda template and hosting guide](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1g7fR5cvCGFq15SJ4iQMclbj0QIeREKu_QP8ftnSaJ4o/edit) are up to date 
- [ ] Ensure the [SIG Schedule](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1adztrJ05mQ_cjatYSnvyiy85KjuI6-GuXsRsP-T2R3k/edit#gid=1543199895) have SIGs assigned for the next few months
  - [ ] Ensure the assigned SIGs in this sheet match the actual SIGs in sigs.yaml. Double check that a SIG hasn't missed an update this past cycle and if they have schedule them for an upcoming meeting

/sig contributor-experience

title: CLA "edge cases" and how to approach them
body:
Howdy! I wanted to open this up in `k/community`, but there's also a superset-ey, omnibus issue around CLAs in kubernetes/kubernetes#27796.

I'm not sure if this is the best place to discuss this, but some interesting cases for contributors are when they:
- transition from individual contributor to employee contributor (or vice versa)
- transition to another company e.g., Red Hat acquisition of CoreOS

I'm personally still under the CoreOS CLA, because I'm concerned that there isn't a well defined process for transitioning to another company, and I don't want to impede my ability to contribute.

There are some great comments on that omnibus thread that ask similar questions:
- https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/27796#issuecomment-327943347
- https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/27796#issuecomment-365554340

It appears that the silver bullet is to contact helpdesk@rt.linuxfoundation.org for assistance, but it would be nice to actually document some of these use cases, so people know what to expect when hitting them (which I'm happy to help do).

Some things I noticed about the Linux Foundation ID:
- one username
- if you're using GitHub as your auth provider (which I did, not sure if that's strictly required or not) then it would make sense that you could only connect that GH account to a single LF identity
- required to use my work email to sign up for the account and the CKA exam
- doesn't appear to support transitioning the account to a different company CLA without helpdesk intervention

It would be cool if I could sign up for one account that held multiple identities (personal, work, etc.) and supported transitioning between different contributor types.

(I'm happy to move this somewhere else, if there's a more appropriate place for this issue.)

cc: @dankohn 

ref:
- #1794 
- kubernetes/kubernetes#27796

/sig contributor-experience
/area contributor-guide

title: Add several already-in-use kind labels to official list
body:
The following kind/ labels are already in wide use in the project, have meaning, and as such should be available in the official master list of labels:

* kind/cleanup: A refactoring, API reorganization, dependency version upgrade, or other "maintenance" code change.
* kind/design: Specifications, API designs, plans for new components and APIs.
* kind/api-change: changes to an existing API, important to track for conformance/compatibility.  Used by SIG-arch, SIG-API
* kind/new-api: brand new APIs, should be pretty rare, but important.  Used by SIG-arch

This is in addition to kind/failing-test and kind/flake, as proposed in #1579.

The following two kind labels are also in use, but should be marked as "deprecated" as they are duplicative of other labels:

* kind/enhancement: duplicates kind/feature
* kind/technical-debt: duplicates kind/cleanup

If this is approved, I'll open a PR against test-infra with the changes.

title: Tracking Issue: Normalize Kind Labels
body:
There are several issues open regarding Kind labels.  This is a tracking issue to track all of them across the project so that people can visualize what the end result will be.

Issues:
* #2014 Lable kind/support should be renamed to triage/
* #1579 Propose replacing github label priority/failing-test with kind/failing-test
* #2013 Add several already-in-use kind labels to official list

Some general points:

1. All else being equal, fewer kind labels is considered a good thing.
2. Kind/ labels which are not explicitly recommended and documented should be considered deprecated.
3. Old kind labels which have not been used since the 1.9 cycle or earlier should be considered deprecated. 
4. Ideally, issues and PRs should be able to treat Kind labels as exclusive (apply only one per PR/issue), although this should not be enforced due to corner cases.

I am vague on how we should be applying this set of rules to K/K vs. organization-wide.  My primary concern is limiting the pool of kind labels in k/k to a relative handful of clearly needed labels.

## New list of canonical Kind labels 

* kind/feature
* kind/bug
* kind/documentation
* kind/failing-test (was priority/failing-test)
* kind/flake (new per #1579)
* kind/cleanup (in use)
* kind/design (in use)
* kind/api-change (in use)
* kind/new-api (in use)

## Deprecated Kind labels:

* kind/support (to triage/support)
* kind/enhancement (duplicates kind/feature)
* kind/technical-debt (duplicates kind/cleanup)

Also officially deprecating these kind labels, which exist but have not been used since 1.9 or earlier:

* kind/friction (?)
* kind/mesos-flake (?)
* kind/old-docs (duplicates kind/documentation)
* kind/postmortem (?)
* kind/upgrade-test-failure (duplicates kind/failing-test) 

## List of Changes To Make

Renames:

* priority/failing-test to kind/failing-test
* kind/support to triage/support

New Labels:

* kind/flake

Existing Labels to be added to labels.md:

* kind/cleanup
* kind/design
* kind/api-change
* kind/new-api

Finally, announce deprecation of all the deprecated labels above, and mark them as such in the label dictionary.

cc @spiffxp

title: Fix mistakes about the example of resource account for burstable pods and typo mistake
body:
Fix mistake about the example about calculating the cpu.shares of a burstable pod (Pod3) with two containers. Since the container "bar" in Pod3 is only specified with resource.limit, so the resource.request of container "bar" is equal to its limits, so request.cpu is 100m, request.memory is 1Gi. 

Therefore, when you calculate the pod level cgroup's cpu.shares should be the sum of resource.request.cpu of container "foo" and "bar",  which is 120m. The cpu share of burstable cgroup should also be modified to 130m.

title: KEP: Security Profile Design Proposal
body:
This is the detailed design proposal for Security Profile.

Security Profile helps managing a secured Kubernetes cluster by solving problems of:

- Management complexity
  - Complicated configuration of control plane components' security-relevant command line flags, correctness of cert/key/config file permissions;
  - Requires deep understanding of Kubernetes policy objects like RBAC, PodSecurityPolicy, NetworkPolicy, ResourceQuota etc;
  - No support for automatic provisioning of namespaced policy objects upon namespace creation;
  - Requires of domain knowledge about security;
  - Requires keeping up with fast evolving Kubernetes security/isolation features, and update configurations accordingly;

- Extra efforts building in-house solutions
  - No standard/common ways to solve the problems;
  - It’s very difficult to make in-house solutions sharable/reusable, as a result, efforts are duplicated solving same/similar problems.

by defining curated settings of:

- Cluster bootstrapping configuration, like command line flags, file permissions, etc
- Cluster-scoped policy objects, like PodSecurityPolicy
- Namespace-scoped policy objects, like NetworkPolicy

And simplify the cluster management by specifying the name of security profile.


_This proposal is looking for sponsorship from sig-auth,
to create a public repo as [https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/security-profiles](),
that community can help curate commonly used security profiles.
Details are described in Release section in the proposal._

/sig auth

/cc @davidopp 
/cc @tallclair 
/cc @ericchiang 
/cc @liggitt

title: docs for mentoring activities at events
CRD versioning design proposal [No Conversion]
body:
CRD versioning proposal is discussed in detail here:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ucf7JwyHpy7QlgHIN2Rst_q6yT0eeN9euzUV6kte6aY/edit

title: Update device manager doc to match 1.10 device plugin API changes.
body:
Hello!

/cc @vikaschoudhary16 @jiayingz @vishh @derekwaynecarr @3xx0 @flx42

I made the following changes
- Updated with the new 1.10 API
- Added a naming section
  - This is a big one, I want to make sure we all use the same names to designate the same components
  - Feel free to comment on this
- Some small rewording

The names introduced here are:
- **Device Plugin**: The pod running on each node which allows kubelet and kubernetes to be "device aware"
- **Device Plugin API**: The gRPC API which allows kubelet and the device plugins to communicate. 
- **Device Plugin API Container**: The container which communicates with kubelet through the Device Plugin API
- **device manager**: The part of Kubelet in charge of managing the device plugins

title: [RFC] SIG-Node initial charter
body:
Co-authored by: @derekwaynecarr @dchen1107 

/sig node

Topics for discussion with @kubernetes/steering-committee review:

1.  working group lifecycle - this proposal empowers a technical lead of a sig to sponsor a working group.  if working groups span sigs, this would mean agreement from a technical lead from each sponsoring sig may be required, and therefore should be common across the project.
1. process to decommission a sub-project - could be a variety of reasons (not healthy, not maintained, no longer endorsed or accepted by the sig).  this proposal makes no statement on the mechanism other than stating technical leads should have the power.

title: KEP: security conformance proposal
body:
## Summary

Security Conformance defines citeria to certify a Kubernetes cluster to be minimally secure.

## Motivation

Configuring a Kubernetes cluster is complicated,
and it's very easy to mis-configure a cluster to be insecure.
The current Kubernetes conformance test suite barely covers security aspects.

/sig auth
/sig testing
/assign @tallclair 

@davidopp @tallclair @ericchiang @liggitt @bgrant0607

title: Add link to sig-list when an incorrect `sig/` command OR when the `needs-sig` label is added to an issue/PR
body:
Not sure if this is the correct repo for this issue. If it isn't, please let me know what would be the right place to file it.

Whenever the @k8s-ci-robot adds a `needs-sig` label, can we link to the list of sigs as well? A lot of people aren't aware of what a SIG is or what labels exist, so some background about that would be very useful while filing issues. It would save overhead while triaging. I often see ppl using `sig/pod`, `sig/networking` etc., 
OR can we display the sig list in response to an incorrect sig label being added?

title: KEP: Promote sysctl annotations to fields
body:
Setting the `sysctl` parameters through annotations provided a successful story
for defining better constraints of running applications.
The `sysctl` feature has been tested by a number of people without any serious
complaints. Promoting the annotations to fields (i.e. to beta) is another step in making the
`sysctl` feature closer towards the stable API.

title: *: Assorted internal-reference cleanups
body:
This is mostly replacing `https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/...` links with relative links, because relative links are easier to maintain.  For example, if you rename `a.md` to `b.md` in a feature branch, updating an `../a.md` to `../b.md` target will work immediately (e.g. during pull-request review), while updating `https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/a.md` to `https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/b.md` will only work after your branch lands the rename in master.

I'm not sure why the `#L1454` fragment was part of the old sig-governance template sigs.yaml link, but it's been there since the template landed in 68658bff (#1830).  I've removed it in this commit.

The Kubernetes Charter README link in the sig-governance template could just be:

    [Kubernetes Charter README]: README.md

but I've sent it down to the project root and back to make life easier on new SIGs which copy/paste the file to a new location in this repository.  With this pull request they'll just need to drop one level of `../` to get the references working from places like `sig-contributor-experience/charter.md`.

I've also chased a few files and anchors as they've moved around, e.g. the `OBSOLETE_templates.md` rename from 18958f82 (#1010) and the "and maintenance" header addition from f471f6b6 (#1215).

This pull request isn't complete, but it's a step in the right direction and all I had time for tonight ;).

title: KEP: Namespace Population
body:
## Summary

Namespace Population is an automated mechanism to make sure the predefined policy objects
(e.g. NetworkPolicy, Role, RoleBinding) are present in selected namespaces.

## Motivation

Kubernetes users create namespaces (self-service namespace creation) and want to
ensure security/isolation policies are enforced between them and other users.
Just like addon manager creates cluster-scope policy objects like PodSecurityPolicy,
ClusterRole, ClusterRoleBinding at cluster creation time.
It creates namespace-scope policy objects during namespace creation time.

This is part of [Security Profile proposal](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/pull/2052)

/sig auth
/sig api-machinery
/sig cluster-lifecycle

/cc @davidopp 
/cc @tallclair 
/cc @ericchiang 
/cc @liggitt 
/cc @bgrant0607 
/cc @roberthbailey 
/cc @lavalamp

title: Update / clarify local e2e tests instructions
body:
Following this document:

https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/e2e-tests.md

Led me to a section that showed how to run the e2e tests locally against a local-up cluster. While I was able to follow the instructions to get the local cluster up and running, hack/e2e.go complained that ginkgo did not exist. Sure enough, it was not present in my `_output` directory. However, once I figured out to run `make all WHAT=vendor/github.com/onsi/ginkgo/ginkgo` the binary showed up and I was able to run the e2e tests.

Did I miss a step in the documentation, or should something be added to note that for running the e2e locally some additional work is required?

title: SIG charter template: Separate SIG and subproject roles
body:
By separating the SIG and subproject roles, we can more tightly scope the previous "Membership for roles tracked in: `sigs.yaml`".  The SIG
roles are tracked there directly, but subproject roles are incorperated by reference.  Now that the subproject roles are in their own subsection, we can spend a bit more time talking about that indirection.

I've removed "Seed members established at SIG founding" from the chairs entry, because its already discussed in `/committee-steering/governance/README.md` (step 4).  There's no need to record that procedure in the charter itself, because the initial membership can be recovered from the version controlled history of `sigs.yaml`.

I've split the previous "Members" role into a SIG entry and a subproject entry to clarify that distinction.  The previous member line-items are mostly handled in other places now:

* "maintain health of at least one subproject or the health of the SIG", "show sustained contributions to at least one subproject or to the SIG", "hold some documented role", and "Includes all reviewers and approvers" are now addressed by the member definitions.
* "build new functionality" is not particularly clear, and for most subprojects anyone can contribute issues, pull requests, etc. without being a formal subproject member.
* "participate in decision making for the subprojects they hold roles in" is redundant with the other role definitions.

I've split the previous "Subproject Owners" into subproject approvers and reviewers.  This lets us define subproject members to include both
approvers and reviewers while restricting control over some activity (adjusting the `OWNERS` file) to approvers.  The "alter their own `OWNERS`" wording makes that line generic enough to allow for managing both approvers and reviewers, as well as anything else that the `OWNERS` file covers.

There is no implicit `OWNERS` nesting, all `OWNERS` entries must be listed in `sigs.yaml`.  This is a bit more work for `sigs.yaml` maintainers, but allows for owner/approver calculation without walking all referenced repositories.  We also have existing cases where parent and child `OWNERS` files are in different SIGs/subprojects.  For example, kubernetes/kubernetes has `/test/e2e/apps/OWNERS` in the workloads-api
subproject of SIG Apps, while the parent `/test/OWNERS` is in the testing-commons subproject of SIG Testing.

Because of the repo-root restriction, security contacts have an added wrinkle for nested subprojects.  The way I've worded it, kubernetes/kubernetes security contact would be a member of all subprojects with an `OWNERS` file in that repository (assuming the associated SIG had adopted wording like what I'm proposing with this pull request).  Members don't have many teeth (they mostly SHOULD approve things), and security contacts will have lots of trust, so the broad association here shouldn't cause any problems.

I've added a SHOULD for estabilishing security contacts for new repositories.  This will probably happen even without the reminder, but it's nice to be explicit.

I've also made assorted minor copy-edits near lines I touched.

CC @cblecker, since I'm spinning this off from our discussion [here][1].

[1]: https://github.com/kubernetes/community/pull/2181#issuecomment-391464195

title: Add In-Tree Plugin to CSI Driver Migration Design Proposal
body:
cc @jsafrane, @msau42, @saad-ali

This is the design proposal for the mechanism to migrate In-Tree Storage Plugins to use CSI Drivers instead. PTAL

Biggest caveats to look out for:
* Dynamic provisioning creates CSI PV's, not in-tree plugin PV's
* Nodes must be drained before turning feature on/off in Kubelet
* Deprecation of in-tree plugins will be a long pull, and at some point might break people if user does not take specific action on their self-managed clusters.
* Migration turned on/off with feature gates, may be un-configurable by users in managed environments
